intro: Lappago setacea, commonly known as the hairy lappago, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in grassy areas or along streambanks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
